description.narrative: For conflict mitigation it is important to reach approximately the same number of Dinka and Mundari with the programme to balance the approach. In total around 128,000 people will participate in the programme, either passively or actively, and approximately 21,000 households.

participating-org.narrative: Payam and County Water and Health Departments will be actively involved in all the activities related to water and sanitation.

policy-marker.narrative: The main objective of this programme is to contribute to improved human security and rule of law through fostering local stability among competing groups and contribute to increased legitimacy of the local government in the targeted area.

description.narrative: Incoming fund from RECON2 programme, August 2013
Incoming fund from RECON4 programme, December 2013
Incoming fund from RECON4 programme, February 2013
Incoming fund from RECON4 programme, June 2014
Incoming fund from RECON4 programme, October 2012

transaction.ref: Total Expenditures under this activity until end of project

description.narrative: Improved access to basic services
By the end of the project, at least 35% of the targeted beneficiaries indicate that they defecate at a private or communal latrine

comment.narrative: 16.1% in Terekeka County indicates to defecate in a latrine; 20.5% in Bor South County; 18.1% in both counties combined (Baseline Report 2013). Latrine coverage monitored by internal using tracking tool 3.6."
46 household latrines have been constructed so far. The percentage increase will be verified through a household survey during the mid term review which is planned for 2014.

Terekeka: 26 % of the targeted beneficiaries indicate that they defecate at a private or communal latrine. Bor South + Gameiza: 13.1 % of the targeted beneficiaries indicate that they defecate at a private or communal latrine. Average = 19.55%

Terekeka: Field visits and TAYA (local partner of ZOA ) indicate that an uptake of latrine usage has been best in Tali Centre but much less in Tindilo and Rijong Centres. This was not verifiable since a formal KAP survey was not conducted in the area in 2016. Bor South + Gameiza: No assessment done due to ascertaining the 2016 levels of latrine usage.

Terekeka: Latrine coverage has slightly improved from 18.7% last year to 27.6% following the mobilisation and construction of an additional 22 latrines. As at the end of the year the program had mobilised the community to construct a cumulative total of 68 household latrines. Bor South + Garmeiza: No activities in 2014

description.narrative: By the end of the project, 60% of the targeted beneficiaries indicate that they use a mosquito net

comment.narrative: "43.1% in Terekeka County indicate to use a mosquito net 36.1% in Bor South County 39.8% in both counties (Baseline Report 2013). Distribution of mosquito nets is monitored by using internal tracking tool 3.7."
2525 community members supported with mosquito nets which should potentially lead to an improved mosquito nets coverage. Will be verified during the mid term review which is planned for 2014.
Not applicable - activity deleted and not funded.
Not applicable - activity deleted and not funded.
Not applicable - activity deleted and not funded.
Not applicable - activity deleted and not funded.

Terekeka: An additional 630 people in Terekeka county were reached with the local Mundari-mosquito net. This resulted into a percentage increment of 1.2% in Terekeka County. Bor South + Gameiza: No activities in 2014

description.narrative: Improved capacity of partner organizations, local government and community based organizations to support continued improved access to water for cattle, agriculture and basic services
All local government partners and NGO partner organisations capacitated in management and finance skills

comment.narrative: No baseline info. Capacity is monitored by using internal tracking tool 3.9.
No SPCM-specific activity for the area in 2015.
No SPCM-specific activity for the area in 2016.

Terekeka: TAYA staff sponsored to attend a training course in project proposal writing. TAYA supported to write and submit a proposal to IOM for the rapid response funding from USAID/OFDA. A total of 3 Payams were supported to recruit Agriculture extension officers to provide the needed agricultural extension services. The program supported 1 county water department with office stationary and furniture. Bor South + Gameiza: No activities in 2014

"TAYA supported to develop their own Strategic Plan 2014-2018 and provided with a motorbike. 2 TAYA staff sponsored to go for a specialised training in peacebuilding. Compass supported to streamline finance systems and set up accountability and control systems."

description.narrative: At least 3 Water Departments capacitated by technical assistance and training

comment.narrative: No baseline info. Capacity is monitored by using internal tracking tool 3.9.
No SPCM-specific activity for the LGA water department.
No SPCM-specific activity for the LGA water department.

Terekeka: 1 Water department supported with office furniture and stationary. 3 Payams supported to recruit a Payam Agriculture extension officer to provide agriculture extension services to local farmers. Bor South + Gameiza: No activities in 2014
"2 County Agriculture Departments supported with office furniture and stationary. 5 Payam administrations supported with office furniture and stationary."

description.narrative: Over the 4-year programme period: 1 County Department and at least 6 staff from partner NGOs demonstrate competent skills in HR, M & E, project and financial management

comment.narrative: No baseline info. Capacity is monitored by using internal tracking tool 3.9.
No progress yet on this indicator.

Terekeka: 2 from TAYA staff and 4 from local government trained on gender-based violence. They were instrumental in conducting sensitization sessions for police, local chiefs and Payam administrators in Tali, Rijong and Tindilo. TAYA helped form 3 teams of Peace Committees in Tali (13 members), Tindilo (11 members) and Rijong (11 members) that are functional in resolving local community conflicts in the 3 Payams. Bor South + Gameiza: County Department and NGO staff not assessed on competence. Some of the supported partner staff training aspects are incomplete e.g. the TAYA staff in courses."

Terekeka: At least 4 partner organisation staff members are competently able to develop project proposals and engage in fundraising. The programme further sponsored 4 partner staff to attend a quick book finance course in Katigiri. Bor South + Gameiza: No activities in 2014

description.narrative: Improved capacity of relevant organizations, institutions and local government to prevent and mitigate conflict and sustain peace
By the end of the project, 60 local and community leaders trained to develop by-laws related to early and forced marriages

comment.narrative: N/A
53 community leaders were trained about the dangers of early/ forced marriages, conflict resolution and the rule of law.

Terekeka: 14 local leaders - Payam directors, traditional and church leaders(13 men and 1 woman) from Tali and Tindilo contributed to 2 community meetings on amending by-laws related to 12 traditional leaders. By-laws for Tali, Tindilo and Rijong passed on to Terekeka County Commissioner for endorsement. Bor South + Gameiza: •12 traditional leaders from Gameiza Payam (Payam Admin, 5 Boma Chiefs, Women and Youth Leaders ) supported by a lawyer that contributed to the drafting of by-laws on forced/early marriages for Gemeiza Payam. • 50 leaders (of Payam, church and traditional ) from Kolnyang and Anyidi Payams were trained on human rights, the rule of law and peace building. They were supported to identify, dialogue and draft proposals to resolve local inter-tribal and inter-clan related conflicts in their respective communities, through Peace Committees."

Terekeka: No info on trainings, but draft bylaws on early and forced marriage awaits legal endorsement by County authorities. Bor South + Gameiza: 481-community, cultural and religious leaders attended dialogue sessions from both the Mundari and Dinka communities. A key resolution: 30 herds of cattle recommended dowry price

The program organised 3 dialogue meetings on ending child and forced marriages with local leaders. A total of 37 community leaders attended ( 27 were males and 10 female). The dialogue sessions led to the development of draft by-laws regulating child and forced marriages in the 3 Payams of Tali, Tindilo and Rejong Payam.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, 60 local and community leaders trained to implement resolutions related to the movement of cattle

comment.narrative: N/A
Our partner RCDI has designed a regulations framework for the movement of cattle; is now under review with the County Authorities. Training is planned for 2014.

Terekeka: 35 Payam participants (13 from Tali, 11 from Tindilo and 11 from Rejing) attended a refresher course on capacity building of peace committees to promote peace and reconciliation and resolve conflicts in their respective communities. Bor South + Gameiza: 18 (M=15, F = 3) church leaders and peace committee members trained to facilitate community dialogue and facilitate community based solutions. This has resulted in an increase of the number of peacefully resolved conflicts.
Terekeka: 42 Payam participants trained. Bor South + Gameiza: No new trainings, but refer to 1.2.1 for related outcome
The training was not conducted yet as some Payams had not completed the development of cattle movement permits.

description.narrative: Improved coverage and management of water for cattle and people
By the end of the project, at least 30% of the targeted beneficiaries in Terekeka County indicate that their cattle have access to man made water points during the dry season

comment.narrative: 18.4% of the respondents in Terekeka County indicate: good or average access (data from Baseline Report 2013).
No survey was conducted to generate this information. Will be part of the KAP survey to be done later in 2015.

Terekeka: 34% target beneficiaries had 'good' or 'average' access to man made water points during the dry season. Bor South + Gameiza: 47.7% of targeted beneficiaries had 'good' or 'average' access to man made water points during the dry season. Average = 40.85%

Terekeka: Completed construction of the Golo dam (at Mijiki in Mundari land) has contributed to improved relationships between Mundari and Dinka Tirol, as well as neighbouring Moru tribesmen since the mentioned communities no longer clash over wetlands during the dry season cattle grazing. An opportunity for constructing a cattle water point at Tindilo was missed out due to inability of the local community counterparts to make matching contributions. Bor South + Gameiza: No quantitative assessment made in 2016. Overall picture is that water for people has been achieved to greater extend as compared to water for cattle. With water points well-maintained, SPHERE minimum standards are met relating to access to water. Sustaining repairs of water points is still an issue due to shortage of spare-parts supplies and access to very remote water points.
This will be verified through a household survey during the mid term review which is planned for 2014.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, the percentage of bomas in the targeted payams with access to natural and man made water points for cattle within the County during the dry season has increased with 20%

comment.narrative: Monitored by using internal tracking tool 3.2. It is about the number of bomas in Tali Payam, Tindilo Payam and Rijong Payam.
No quantitative assessments made in 2016
No survey was conducted to generate this information. Will be assessed after the rainy season 2015.

Terekeka: 4 new Bomas out of 10 Bomas in West Nile have 4 repaired handpumps. Total: 9 bore hole water points were rehabilitated in Tali, Tindilo and Rijong payams. (500 people per bole hole, therefore 4,500 people have access to water). Construction of 1 dam (Golo in Mijiki Boma) added a water reservoir to serve 3,000 cattle). Bor South + Gameiza: 5 new Bomas out of 11 Bomas in East Nile have access to 1 new and 6 repaired handpumps. Total for the area: 1 new bore hole water points was drilled including a cattle trough to enhance access of water for cattle. In Anyara and Khorshumba Bomas in Gameiza Payam 6 repaired water points enhanced access to water for Palek, Khorshumba, Gameiza Centre, Pokor, Sudan Safari and Biar Bomas of Gameiza Payam.
The dam construction which will positively influence this indicator will be finalized before the start of the rains in 2014.

description.narrative: Improved productivity of agriculture
By the end of the project, average crop production per beneficiary household engaged in agriculture in the targeted communities has increased by 10%

comment.narrative: Crop production is monitored by using internal tracking tool 3.4.

According to the MTR, households interviewed indicated an improvement in production but it was not possible to establish the level of percentage increase per household since no formal statistical survey was conducted. Will be part of the KAP survey process, to be done later in 2015.
No quantitative assessments made in 2016

Terekeka: No reliable data established Bor South + Gameiza: 2015 production data: Maize = 260.1kg Sorghum = 211.37 kg Groundnuts = 425.38kg Cowpeas = 101.57kg Sesame = 68.52kg With missing 2013 baseline data, change in production could not be measured.
The baseline of crop production per household and per farmer group has been taken in last quarter of 2013. In last quarter of 2014 a measurement of this output indicator will take place.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, at least 30% of beneficiary households engaged in agriculture in the targeted communities has added one or more crops to their portfolio compared to the baseline

comment.narrative: "Households are growing the following: Sorghum: 86% Maize: 86% Groundnuts: 56% Millet: 9% Cassava: 3% Sweet potatoes: 2% (Baseline Report 2013)"

A total of 694 farmers from 34 farmer groups have been supported with higher yielding varieties of maize, groundnuts and sorghum. In addition, emphasis has been put on growing vegetables. The percentage increase will be verified through a household survey during the mid term review which is planned for 2014.

A variety of improved crop, vegetable and fruit seeds were introduced in 10 farmer groups of 191 members in 2014. The newly introduced crops include tomatoes, onions, cabbages, mangoes and oranges have been planted by the community in the project area.

Terekeka: No SPCM-specific interventional crops added to the tomatoes, onions, cabbages, mangoes and oranges introduced in 2014. Bor South + Gameiza: 54.39% of target community households had 8 new crops added to HH agricultural production(cow peas, sesame, tomatoes, onions, cabbages, mangoes and oranges)

Terekeka: No specific interventions on new crops. Field visits indicated an increasing interest in vegetable growing by households, but ZOA has not invested in seed supply systems in the area. Bor South + Gameiza: 900 households (in 45 farmer groups) supported with agricultural production tools and advisory services.

description.narrative: Increased inter-tribal respect, cooperation and recognition of traditional and national law supported by improved capacity of local governance in the targeted areas
By the end of the project, 50% of the conflicts between Dinka and Mundari over resources for cattle is resolved by inter-tribal meetings

comment.narrative: No baseline info. Monitored by using internal tracking tool 3.1.

20/27 reported conflicts were resolved peacefully. This represents 74.1% of the conflicts were resolved though dialogue (Terekeka). 49/77 inter-tribal conflicts reported was resolved peacefully. This represents 63.63% of the conflicts having been resolved though dialogue (Bor South + Gameiza). Average = 68.87%
Is an outcome indicator, not output
No new data collected in 2016 for Terekeka. Bor South + Gameiza: 52/84 tracked conflicts were resolved peacefully through dialogue, representing 62% of all conflicts reported. Average = 68.05%
Terekeka: 1/ 3 inter-tribal conflicts reported was resolved peacefuly. This represents 33% of the conflicts having been resolved though dialogue. Bor South/Gameiza: No activities in 2014

description.narrative: By the end of the project, bylaws regulating early and forced marriages are in place in at least 50% of the targeted payams and effectiveness of bylaws is established

comment.narrative: No bylaws regulating early and forced marriage are in place in the 6 payams.
Is an outcome indicator, not output
Terekaka: 3/6 targeted Payams (Tali, Tindilo and Rejong) have drafted by-laws regulating child and forced mariages.These by-laws are still being refined. Bor South/Gameiza: No activities in 2014

Terekeka: 3/3 Payams have draft bylaws (Tali, Tindilo and Rejong) regulating child and forced marriages. Bor South + Gameiza: 1/3 Payams (Gameiza) have draft bylaws regulating child and forced marriages. Average = 66.5%

Terekeka: 3/3 Payams have draft bylaws (Tali, Tindilo and Rejong) regulating child and forced marriages. Bor South + Gameiza: 1/3 Payams (Gameiza) have draft bylaws regulating child and forced marriages. Average = 66.5%

description.narrative: By the end of the project, at least 20% of the targeted beneficiaries indicates an improvement in their perception of shared identity and shared values with the other tribal group (Dinka or Mundari)

comment.narrative: The Positive Perception Index of the opposing tribe is 24.7%. Calculation can be found in the Positive Perception Index.
Is an outcome indicator, not output
No info

Terekaka: Community members interviewed during the Midterm survey highlighted some improvement in their relationship with their neigbouring tribes evidanced by reduced incidences of cattle thefts and revange attacks. It was however not possible to establish the percentage level of perception since no survey was conducted. A KAP survey will be establised at the end of 2015. Bor South/Gameiza: no activities in 2014

Terekeka: At least 20 % of the targeted beneficiaries indicates an improvement in their perception of shared identity and shared values. Bor South + Gameiza: At least 84% of the targeted beneficiaries indicates an improvement in their perception of shared identity and shared values. Average = 52%

description.narrative: Increased opportunities for positive intergroup/ inter-clan activities with respect to peace building and dowry reduction campaigning
By the end of the project, bylaws regulating early and forced marriages are in place in at least 50% of the targeted payams and effectiveness of bylaws is established.

comment.narrative: No bylaws regulating early and forced marriages are in place in the 6 payams.

Bylaws regarding early and forced marriages have been discussed in 3 of the 6 payams. The bylaws were developed and passed by the County Legislative Council and subsequently endorsed by the County Commissioner in Terekeka.

Draft by-laws in place in 3 Payams of Tali Payam. Endorsement by local government council was being awaited. Effectiveness not yet measureable until law is fully established, but indications are that there is covert resistance by some community leaderships since such bylaws would retrain charging more than the recommended 30 cows for dowry.

Terekeka: Draft by-laws have been developed in 3/6 Payams of the project area. Refining of the by-laws is ongoing through support from an experienced legal consultant. At least 40% of the of the activity has been realised.

Terekeka: Draft by-laws in place in 3 Payams of Tali Payam. Endorsement by local government council was being awaited. Effectiveness not yet measureable until law is fully established. Bor South + Gameiza: Draft bylaw for 1 Payam is in place. Effectiveness not yet measureable until law is fully established.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, functional systems are in place in all targeted payams to follow up on regional resolutions regulating the movement of cattle "

comment.narrative: No functional systems are in place in the targeted payams regulating the movement of cattle.

Local chiefs and cattle camp leaders have adapted cattle movement letters/ permits in 3/6 Payams and often issues relating to cattle emerge. This has contributed to improved communication between cattle camp leaders and local chiefs on cattle movements and related ‘rules of engagement.
Our partner RCDI has designed a regulations framework for the movement of cattle; is now under review with the County Authorities.

Terekeka: All 3 Payams (Tali,Tindilo and Rejong) have system of cattle-movement permits authorized by cattle camp leaders in the respective villages. Bor South + Gameiza: Gameiza, Anyidi and Kolnyang cattle camp leaders have written permit protocols for movements across, into or out of the 3 Payams.

Terekeka: All 3 Payams (Tali,Tindilo and Rejong) have system of cattle-movement permits authorized by cattle camp leaders in the respective villages. Inter-Terekeka cattle movements are locally monitored. Cattle to and from outside Terekeka in Q3 of 2015 was highly restricted, authenticated permits to be shown for such movements , even for sale in the capital JUBA. Bor South + Gameiza: Gameiza, Anyidi and Kolnyang cattle camp leaders have written permit protocols for movements across, into or out of the 3 Payams .

description.narrative: By the end of the project, 6 inter tribal sports competitions held

comment.narrative: A total of 4 inter-tribal sports events of traditional wrestling and football were conducted attracting a total of 2206 participants. 1360 of these were males and 846 were females.

Terekeka: 5 wrestling and traditional dancing events between the Dinka and Mundari communities, attracting over 1000 participants from the Mundari and Dinka ethnic groups. Bor South + Gameiza: 2 events were organized (1 traditional dancing ceremony organized between the Mundari Youths from the new Gameiza County and Kolnyang Payam in Bor Count, attracting 400 youths. 1 youth wrestling event organized between Kolnyang and Anyidi communities attracting 40 wrestlers and attendance of over 1000 people.

Terekeka: ●2 football matches between Tali and Tindilo Payams (Mix of Mundari and Dinka players) ●1 wrestling competition organised TAYA for 168 youths (98 males and 70 females) to promote social cohesion amongst youth of Rijong and Tijor Payams. Bor South + Gameiza: 6 inter tribal sports ( 4 wrestling and 2 traditional dancing events) organised attracting a total of 1086 (624 males and 462 females) Mundari and Dinka participants.
Three inter-tribal sports competitions were held to promote peace and unity in and between their communities.

description.narrative: The project received initial approval by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on 28th June 2012 for a total amount of 57% of the proposed budget at the time of submission in March 2012. ZOA was then asked to submit a revised project plan by latest 15th September 2012. The Ministry decided on the revised plan on 16th November 2012, after which ZOA started implementation of the project. ZOA found it best to not start the revised project immediately after submission in September 2012 so not to run the risk of beginning project work on a wrong footing, we considered the operational risks of starting the project without having received the donor’s ultimate directions, too high. Therefore, we could only start full project preparations in second half of November and were left with six weeks in 2012 to this effect. The extent of project activity in 2012 has been limited, work has focused on project preparations mainly. (Actual operations took off in 2013.) Between July and September 2012, ZOA revised the planned activities and budget in response to the budget cut. Thereafter, preliminary structural activities for the smooth rolling out of the project have been concluded in 2012 and local partnerships with organizations on both sides of the project area are established under the project.

title.narrative: Not applicable for this annual report: see narrative above

comment.narrative: "16.1% in Terekeka County indicate to defecate in a latrine; 20.5% in Bor South County; 18.1% in both counties (Baseline Report 2013). Latrine coverage monitored by using internal tracking tool 3.6"

Terekeka: 26 % of the targeted beneficiaries indicate that they defecate at a private or communal latrine. Bor South + Gameiza: 13.1 % of the targeted beneficiaries indicate that they defecate at a private or communal latrine. Average = 19.55%

Terekeka: Latrine coverage has slightly improved from 18.7% last year to 27.6% following the mobilisation and construction of an additional 22 latrines. The low coverage is partly due to the interruption of the program by the conflict. Bor South + Gameiza: No activities in 2014

description.narrative: By the end of the project, at least 80% of the targeted beneficiaries shows a 10 point improvement in the Food Consumption Score as compared to the baseline

comment.narrative: "Food Consumption Score (FSC) of 35.5 for Terekeka County; FCS of 49.8 for Bor South County; FCS of 42.2 is the weighted average for both counties (Baseline report 2013). Monitored by using internal tracking tool 3.5"
Is an outcome indicator, not output
No annual household survey was conducted during the year. It was not possible to generate this data. Data will be gathered in the course of 2015 during the KAP survey.
No assessment done due to insecurity

Terekeka: At least 12% of the targeted beneficiaries show a 10-point improvement in the Food Consumption Score as compared to the baseline survey (of 35.5). Bor South + Gameiza: At least 22.4% of the targeted beneficiaries shows a 10 point improvement in the Food Consumption Score as compared to the baseline (of 49.8). Average = 17.2%
